description: From Middle English spume, from Old French espume, from Latin spÅ«ma.

entries.meaning: Foam or froth of liquid, particularly that of seawater.
examples: No sluggish tide congenial to the glooms; / This, as it frothed by, might have been a bath / For the fiend's glowing hoof - to see the wrath / Of its black eddy bespate with flakes and spumes.

verbs.description: spume (third-person singular simple present spumes, present participle spuming, simple past and past participle spumed)
